title: Pact snaps up Mind Candy's Divinia Knowles in bid to dominate UK coffee market
text:

Tue, Oct 13, 2015, 01:47 BST - UK Markets open in 6 hrs 13 mins Pact snaps up Mind Candy's Divinia Knowles in bid to dominate UK coffee market By Rebecca Burn-Callander | Telegraph – 45 minutes ago 0.00 0.00 
The woman behind Moshi Monsters is to take the coffee start-up from 50 to 500 people 
Divinia Knowles, former president and chief operating officer of Mind Candy, the company behind children’s brand Moshi Monsters, has joined specialist coffee start-up Pact in a surprise move that will see the 37-year-old attempt to turn a new challenger brand into a global sensation. 
Ms Knowles left Mind Candy earlier this month after nine years at the business; she took over as boss of the company when its founder, Michael Acton Smith, stepped down in 2014 . 
She (Munich: SOQ.MU - news ) has just started her new role at Pact following weeks of industry speculation around her next move. 
“Pact is incredibly similar to Mind Candy seven or eight years ago,” Ms Knowles said. “There’s a great vision and mission, a young team full of talented people, and some initial success.” 
Pact, which just shipped its millionth bag of coffee, is aiming to shake up the coffee market. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) roasts high-quality coffee in the UK and guarantees nationwide next-day delivery, growing 11pc per month, according to founder Stephen Rapoport. 
“We’re not interested in building a small lifestyle business,” he said. “We want to change the very nature of one of the largest commodity businesses in the world.” 
Mind Candy has seen sales flag over the past three years but the relaunch of Moshi Monsters and new game World of Warriors, which has made £4m so far, may prop up future revenues. 
“I’ve made lots of mistakes before but I will hopefully do it without the mistakes this time,” said Ms Knowles. “Pact has had lots of success already, which I will build on.” 
Ms Knowles will oversee Pact as it grows from 50 people to 500, Mr Rapoport said. “We need like professionals like Divinia in the business. We can really draw on her experience selling multiple products in multiple markets.” 
Pact has spent the last 18 months designing a new Nespresso-compatible coffee capsule to help the speciality coffee start-up generate mainstream appeal . “We’ve been iterating different roasts and grinds to make it the best on the planet,” Mr Rapoport said, adding that the final product was “95pc there”. 
“We need to be 1,000 times our current size to make an impact on the market.”
